ai-an9:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an9:1.2.1_0: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow other paths were to ask:
ai-an9:1.2.3_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-an9:1.3.1_0: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-an9:1.4.1_0: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow other paths were to ask:
ai-an9:1.4.2_0: ‘Reverends, what is the vital condition for the development of the awakening factors?’ You should answer them:
ai-an9:1.5.1_0: ‘It’s when a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.
ai-an9:1.5.2_0: This is the first vital condition for the development of the awakening factors.
ai-an9:1.6.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an9:1.6.2_0: This is the second vital condition for the development of the awakening factors.
ai-an9:1.7.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an9:1.7.2_0: This is the third vital condition for the development of the awakening factors.
ai-an9:1.8.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
ai-an9:1.8.2_0: This is the fourth vital condition for the development of the awakening factors.
ai-an9:1.9.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an9:1.9.2_0: This is the fifth vital condition for the development of the awakening factors.’

ai-an9:4.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an9:4.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Nandaka was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk.
ai-an9:4.1.3_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall,
ai-an9:4.1.3_1: and after approaching he stood outside the doorway.
ai-an9:4.1.4_0: When he knew the talk had ended he cleared his throat and knocked with the latch.
ai-an9:4.1.5_0: Those monks opened the door for the Fortunate One.
ai-an9:4.2.1_0: and he entered the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out.
ai-an9:4.2.2_0: While sat the Fortunate One said this to venerable Nandaka:
ai-an9:4.2.3_0: “Nandaka, that was a long exposition of the teaching you gave to the mendicants.
ai-an9:4.2.4_0: My back was aching while I stood outside the door waiting for the talk to end.”
ai-an9:4.3.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Nandaka said to the Buddha:
ai-an9:4.3.2_0: “Sir, we didn’t know that the Buddha was standing outside the door.
ai-an9:4.3.3_0: If we’d known, I wouldn’t have said so much.”
ai-an9:4.4.1_0: Then the Buddha, knowing that Nandaka was embarrassed, said to him,

ai-an9:4.4.5_0: talk about the Dhamma, or maintain noble silence.

ai-an9:4.4.10_0: When a mendicant is faithful and ethical, they’re complete in that respect.

ai-an9:4.9.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant teaches the mendicants the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
ai-an9:4.9.4_0: Whenever they do this, there is a good person.
ai-an9:4.10.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant teaches the mendicants the Dhamma ...
ai-an9:4.10.2_0: Whenever they do this, they feel inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma.

ai-an9:4.13.2_0: Whenever they do this, there may be trainee mendicants present, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary. Hearing that teaching, they rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
ai-an9:4.13.3_0: But there, when mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—these teaching blissful meditation in the present life.

ai-an9:5.1.4_0: And what is the power of wisdom?
ai-an9:5.1.5_0: Those qualities that are skillful, unskillful, blameworthy, not to be cultivated, unworthy of the noble ones—and are reckoned as such. They are dark deeds with bright results, criticized by sensible people, and those things that are reckoned as such.

ai-an9:5.2.2_0: One generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives to give up those qualities that are unskillful and considered to be unskillful; those that are blameworthy ... dark ... not to be cultivated ... not worthy of the noble ones and considered to be not worthy of the noble ones.
ai-an9:5.2.3_0: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities are blameless.
ai-an9:5.2.4_0: This is called the power of energy.
ai-an9:5.3.1_0: And what is the power of blamelessness?
ai-an9:5.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has blameless conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-an9:5.3.3_0: This is called the power of blamelessness.
ai-an9:5.4.1_0: And what is the power of being inclusive?

ai-an9:5.4.3_0: giving, kindly words, taking care, and equality.
ai-an9:5.4.4_0: The best of gifts is the gift of the teaching.
ai-an9:5.4.5_0: The best sort of kindly speech is to teach the Dhamma again and again to someone who is engaged and who lends an ear.
ai-an9:5.4.6_0: The best way of taking care is to encourage, settle, and ground the unfaithful in ethics.
ai-an9:5.4.6_2: They encourage others to do the same.

ai-an9:18.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the observance of the sabbath with its nine factors is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.
ai-an9:18.1.2_0: And how should it be observed?
ai-an9:18.1.3_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-an9:18.1.4_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They are scrupulous and kind, and live full of compassion for all living beings.
ai-an9:18.1.5_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I’ll be scrupulous and kind, and live full of compassion for all living beings.
ai-an9:18.1.6_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an9:18.2.1_0: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up high and luxurious beds. They sleep in a low place, either a small bed or a straw mat.
ai-an9:18.2.2_0: I, too, for this day and night will give up high and luxurious beds. I’ll sleep in a low place, either a small bed or a straw mat.
ai-an9:18.2.3_0: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’
ai-an9:18.3.1_0: They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-an9:18.3.1_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-an9:18.4.1_0: The observance of the sabbath with its nine factors in this way is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.”
ai-an9:19.1.1_0: “Mendicants, tonight, several glorious deities, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me.
ai-an9:19.1.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping me, they stood on one side.
ai-an9:19.1.2_0: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.
ai-an9:19.1.3_0: We politely rose for them, but we didn’t bow.
ai-an9:19.1.4_0: And so, having not fulfilled our duty, full of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a lesser realm.’
ai-an9:19.2.1_0: Then several other deities came to me and said:
ai-an9:19.2.2_0: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.
ai-an9:19.2.3_0: We politely rose for them and bowed, but we didn’t offer a seat.
ai-an9:19.2.4_0: And so, having not fulfilled our duty, full of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a lesser realm.’
ai-an9:19.3.1_0: Then several other deities came to me and said:
ai-an9:19.3.2_0: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.
ai-an9:19.3.3_0: We politely rose, bowed, and offered them a seat. But we didn’t mount their joined palms.
ai-an9:19.3.4_0: they don’t listen to the teachings ...
ai-an9:19.3.5_0: they’re not easy to hear the teaching ...
ai-an9:19.3.6_0: they’re very pure, but don’t we understand the teaching. ...

ai-an9:19.3.8_0: they examine the meaning of the teachings they’ve remembered, but, having understood the meaning and the teaching, they practice accordingly.
ai-an9:19.3.9_0: And so, having not fulfilled our duty, full of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a lesser realm.’
ai-an9:19.4.1_0: Then several other deities came to me and said:
ai-an9:19.4.2_0: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.
ai-an9:19.4.3_0: We politely rose, bowed, and offered them a seat. We shared as best we could. We sat nearby to listen to the teachings, lent an ear, memorized them, and examined their meaning. Understanding the teaching and the meaning we practiced accordingly.
ai-an9:19.4.4_0: And so, having fulfilled our duty, free of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a superior realm.’
ai-an9:19.4.5_0: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
ai-an9:19.4.5_1: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later, like those former deities.”

ai-an9:22.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you about three wild colts and three wild people; three excellent horses and three excellent people; and three fine thoroughbred people.

ai-an9:22.2.3_0: Another wild colt is fast and beautiful, but not well proportioned.
ai-an9:22.2.4_0: While another wild colt is fast, beautiful, and well proportioned.

ai-an9:23.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you nine things rooted in the teaching.
ai-an9:23.1.2_0: And what are the nine things rooted in craving?
ai-an9:23.1.3_0: Craving is a cause of seeking. Seeking is a cause of gaining material possessions. Gaining material possessions is a cause of assessing. Assessing is a cause of desire and lust. Desire and lust is a cause of attachment. Attachment is a cause of possessiveness. Possessiveness is a cause of stinginess. Stinginess is a cause of safeguarding. Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
ai-an9:23.1.4_0: These are the nine things rooted in craving.”
ai-an9:24.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are nine abodes of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.1.3_0: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.
ai-an9:24.1.4_0: This is the first abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.2.1_0: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in Brahmā’s Host through the first absorption.
ai-an9:24.2.2_0: This is the second abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.3.1_0: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.
ai-an9:24.3.2_0: This is the third abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.4.1_0: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods replete with glory.
ai-an9:24.4.2_0: This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.5.1_0: There are sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything, such as the gods who are non-percipient beings.
ai-an9:24.5.2_0: This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.6.1_0: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.
ai-an9:24.6.2_0: This is the sixth abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.7.1_0: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
ai-an9:24.7.2_0: This is the seventh abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.8.1_0: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
ai-an9:24.8.2_0: This is the eighth abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.9.1_0: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. They have been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-an9:24.9.2_0: This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.
ai-an9:24.10.1_0: These are the nine abodes of sentient beings.”
ai-an9:25.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a mendicant’s mind has been well consolidated with wisdom it’s appropriate for them to say:
ai-an9:25.1.2_0: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
ai-an9:25.2.1_0: And how is a mendicant’s mind well consolidated with wisdom?
ai-an9:25.2.2_0: The mind is well consolidated with wisdom when they know: ‘My mind is without greed.’

ai-an9:25.2.6_0: ... ‘My mind is not liable to become hateful.’
ai-an9:25.2.7_0: ... ‘My mind is not liable to become deluded.’
ai-an9:25.2.8_0: ... ‘My mind is not liable to return to sensual pleasures.’
ai-an9:25.2.9_0: ... ‘My mind is not liable to return to rebirth in the realm of luminous form.’

ai-an9:31.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these nine progressive cessations.
ai-an9:31.1.3_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, sensual perceptions have ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.4_0: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.5_0: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.6_0: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.7_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.8_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.9_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.10_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.11_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
ai-an9:31.1.12_0: These are the nine progressive cessations.”

ai-an9:37.2.7_0: The body itself is actually present, and so are those touches. Yet one will not experience that sense-field.”
ai-an9:37.3.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to Venerable Ānanda:
ai-an9:37.3.2_0: “Reverend Ānanda, is one who doesn’t experience that sense-field actually percipient or not?”
ai-an9:37.3.3_0: “Reverend, one who doesn’t experience that sense-field is actually percipient, not non-percipient.”
ai-an9:37.4.1_0: “But what does one who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceive?”
ai-an9:37.4.2_0: “Reverend, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
ai-an9:37.4.3_0: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way.

ai-an9:37.5.2_0: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way.

ai-an9:37.7.1_0: Reverend, one time I was staying near Sāketa in the deer park in Añjana Wood.
ai-an9:37.7.2_0: Then, friend, the resident nun approached me,
ai-an9:37.7.2_1: and after approaching and worshipping me, he stood on one side.
ai-an9:37.7.2_2: The nun who was standing on one side said to me:
ai-an9:37.7.3_0: ‘Sir, Ānanda, regarding the immersion that does not lean forward or pull back, and is not held in place by forceful suppression.
ai-an9:37.7.4_0: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, one is not anxious.
ai-an9:37.7.5_0: What did the Buddha say was the fruit of this immersion?’
ai-an9:37.8.1_0: When she said this, I said to her:
ai-an9:37.8.2_0: ‘Sister, regarding the immersion that does not lean forward or pull back, and is not held in place by forceful suppression.
ai-an9:37.8.3_0: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, one is not anxious.
ai-an9:37.8.4_0: The Buddha said that the fruit of this immersion is enlightenment.’
ai-an9:37.8.5_0: One who doesn’t experience that sense-field perceives in this way, too.”

ai-an9:38.1.1_0: Then two brahmin cosmologists went to the Fortunate One,
ai-an9:38.1.1_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with the Fortunate One
ai-an9:38.1.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-an9:38.1.2_1: While sitting on one side those brahmins said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-an9:38.2.1_0: “Master Gotama, Pūraṇa Kassapa claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
ai-an9:38.2.2_0: ‘While I was constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
ai-an9:38.2.4_0: ‘I know and see the world with its gods, Māras and Brahmās.’
ai-an9:38.2.5_0: And the Jain leader Nāṭaputta also claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
ai-an9:38.2.6_0: ‘While I was constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
ai-an9:38.2.8_0: ‘I know and see the world with its gods, Māras and Brahmās.’
ai-an9:38.2.9_0: These two claim to speak from knowledge, but they directly contradict each other. Which one of them speaks the truth, and which falsehood?”

ai-an9:38.3.4_0: I will teach you the Dhamma.

ai-an9:39.1.1_0: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
ai-an9:39.1.2_0: In that battle the demons won and the gods lost.
ai-an9:39.1.3_0: Defeated, the gods fled north with the demons in pursuit.
ai-an9:39.1.6_0: Why don’t we engage them in battle a second time?’
ai-an9:39.1.7_0: And so a second battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
ai-an9:39.1.8_0: And for a second time the demons won and the gods lost.

ai-an9:39.2.3_0: Why don’t we engage them in battle a third time?’

ai-an9:39.2.5_0: And for a third time the demons won and the gods lost.

ai-an9:39.2.7_0: When they had entered their castle, they thought,

ai-an9:40.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a wild bull elephant is engrossed in the pasture, but other elephants—males, females, younglings, or cubs—got there first and trampled the grass, the wild bull elephant is horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
ai-an9:40.1.2_0: When the wild bull elephant is engrossed in the pasture, but other elephants—males, females, younglings, or cubs—eat the broken branches that he has dragged down, the wild bull elephant is horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
ai-an9:40.1.3_0: When a wild bull elephant has plunged into the pool, but other elephants—males, females, younglings, or cubs—got there first and stirred up the water with their trunks, the wild bull elephant is horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
ai-an9:40.1.4_0: When a wild bull elephant has come out of the pool and the female elephants bump into him, the wild bull elephant is horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
ai-an9:40.2.1_0: At that time the wild bull elephant thinks:
ai-an9:40.2.2_0: ‘These days I live crowded by other males, females, younglings, and cubs.
ai-an9:40.2.3_0: I ate the grass they’d trampled, and they ate the broken branches I’d dragged down.
ai-an9:40.2.4_0: Why don’t I live alone, withdrawn from the herd?’
ai-an9:40.2.5_0: After some time he lives alone, withdrawn from the herd, and he eats untrampled grass, and other elephants don’t eat the broken branches he has dragged down. He doesn’t drink muddy water, and the female elephants don’t bump into him after his bath.
ai-an9:40.3.1_0: At that time the wild bull elephant thinks:
ai-an9:40.3.2_0: ‘Formerly I lived crowded by other males, females, younglings, and cubs. I ate the grass they’d trampled, and they ate the broken branches I’d dragged down. I drank muddy water, and after my bath the female elephants bumped into me.
ai-an9:40.3.2_1: I ate the grass they’d trampled, and they ate the broken branches I’d dragged down.
ai-an9:40.3.2_2: I drank muddy water, and after my bath the female elephants bumped into me. Now I live alone, and I’m free of all these things.’ He breaks off a branch and scratches his body, happily relieving his itches.
ai-an9:40.4.1_0: In the same way, when a mendicant lives crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and by teachers of other paths and their disciples, they think:
ai-an9:40.4.2_0: ‘These days I live crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples.
ai-an9:40.4.3_0: Why don’t I live alone, withdrawn from the herd?’
ai-an9:40.4.4_0: So they frequent a secluded lodging.
ai-an9:40.4.5_0: Gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down cross-legged, with his body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there.
ai-an9:40.5.1_0: Giving up desire for the world, he meditates with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
ai-an9:40.5.2_0: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.
ai-an9:40.5.3_0: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
ai-an9:40.5.4_0: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
ai-an9:40.5.5_0: Giving up doubt, he meditates having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
ai-an9:40.5.6_0: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

ai-an9:41.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town called Uruvelakappa.
ai-an9:41.1.2_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Uruvelakappa for alms.
ai-an9:41.1.3_0: Then, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,
ai-an9:41.1.4_0: “Ānanda, you stay right here, while I plunge deep into the Great Wood for the day’s meditation.”
ai-an9:41.1.6_0: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Great Wood and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-an9:41.2.1_0: The householder Tapussa went to Venerable Ānanda
ai-an9:41.2.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping venerable Ānanda, he sat down on one side.
ai-an9:41.2.1_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:
ai-an9:41.3.1_0: “Sir, Ānanda, we are laypeople who enjoy sensual pleasures. We like sensual pleasures, we love them and take joy in them.
ai-an9:41.3.2_0: But renunciation seems like an abyss.
ai-an9:41.3.3_0: I have heard that in this teaching and training there are very young mendicants whose minds are eager for renunciation; they’re confident, settled, and decided about it. They see it as peaceful.
ai-an9:41.3.4_0: Renunciation is the dividing line between the multitude and the mendicants in this teaching and training.”
ai-an9:41.4.1_0: “Householder, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
ai-an9:41.4.2_0: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.
ai-an9:41.4.3_0: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
ai-an9:41.5.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda together with Tapussa went to the Buddha.
ai-an9:41.5.2_2: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-an9:41.6.2_0: ‘Sir, Ānanda, we are laypeople who enjoy sensual pleasures. We like a layperson who enjoy sensual pleasures. We like a negligent householders to enjoy sensual pleasures. We like a indulgence in sensual pleasures.’
ai-an9:41.6.3_0: I have heard that in this teaching and training there are very young mendicants whose minds are eager for renunciation; they’re confident, settled, and decided about it. They see it as peaceful.
ai-an9:41.6.4_0: Renunciation is the dividing line between the multitude and the mendicants in this teaching and training.”
ai-an9:41.7.2_0: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought,
ai-an9:41.7.4_0: But my mind wasn’t eager for renunciation; it wasn’t confident, settled, and decided about it. I didn’t see it as peaceful.
ai-an9:41.7.6_0: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind isn’t eager for renunciation, and not confident, settled, and decided about it? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’
ai-an9:41.7.8_0: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of renunciation, and so I haven’t developed that.
ai-an9:41.7.9_0: That’s why my mind isn’t eager for renunciation, and not confident, settled, and decided about it. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’
ai-an9:41.7.11_0: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, I would cultivate that.
ai-an9:41.7.12_0: It’s possible that my mind would be eager for renunciation; it would be confident, settled, and decided about it. And I would see it as peaceful.’
ai-an9:41.7.13_0: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of sensual pleasures and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of renunciation and developed that.
ai-an9:41.7.14_0: Then my mind was eager for renunciation; it was confident, settled, and decided about it. I saw it as peaceful.
ai-an9:41.7.15_0: And so, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I was entering and remaining in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an9:41.7.16_0: While I was in that meditation, perceptions and attentions accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me.
ai-an9:41.7.17_0: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.
ai-an9:41.7.18_0: In the same way, when perceptions and attentions accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me, that was an affliction for me.
ai-an9:41.8.2_0: ‘Why don’t I, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled ... enter and remain in the second absorption?’
ai-an9:41.8.3_0: But my mind wasn’t eager to stop placing the mind; it wasn’t confident, settled, and decided about it. I didn’t see it as peaceful.
ai-an9:41.8.5_0: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind isn’t eager to stop placing the mind, and not confident, settled, and decided about it? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’
ai-an9:41.8.7_0: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of placing the mind, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of not placing the mind, and so I haven’t developed that.
ai-an9:41.8.8_0: That’s why my mind isn’t eager to stop placing the mind, and not confident, settled, and decided about it. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’

ai-an9:61.2.1_0: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures ... enters and remains in the first absorption.
